member.name: IConnector.ConnectTo
member.summary: The ConnectTo method connects this connector to a connector in another device-topology object.
member.param: The other connector. This parameter points to the interface of the connector object that represents the connector in the other device topology. The caller is responsible for releasing its counted reference to the IConnector interface when it is no longer needed. The ConnectTo method obtains its own reference to this interface.

returns.para: If the method succeeds, it returns S_OK. If it fails, possible return codes include, but are not limited to, the values shown in the following table.

listheader.description: The current connector and remote connector pointed to by pConnectTo, have the same direction of data flow. A connector with data-flow direction "In" must be connected to another connector with data-flow direction "Out" to create a valid connection in the topology. To determine the data flow of a connector, call .
The object pointed to by pConnectTo is not a valid connector object.
One of the two connectors is already attached to another connector. For information about this macro, see the Windows SDK documentation.

member.name: IConnector.Disconnect
member.summary: The Disconnect method disconnects this connector from another connector.

returns.para: If the method succeeds, it returns S_OK. If it fails, possible return codes include, but are not limited to, the values shown in the following table.

listheader.description: A permanent connection cannot be disconnected. For information about this macro, see the Windows SDK documentation.

member.name: IConnector.GetConnectedTo
member.summary: The GetConnectedTo method gets the connector to which this connector is connected.
member.param: Pointer to a pointer variable into which the method writes the address of the interface of the other connector object. Through this method, the caller obtains a counted reference to the interface. The caller is responsible for releasing the interface, when it is no longer needed, by calling the interface's Release method. If the GetConnectedTo call fails, *ppConTo is NULL.

returns.para: If the method succeeds, it returns S_OK. If it fails, possible return codes include, but are not limited to, the values shown in the following table.

listheader.description: This connector is not connected, or the other side of the connection is not another device topology (for example, a Software_IO connection).
The device topology on the other side of the connection is not active (that is, the device state is not DEVICE_STATE_ACTIVE).

member.name: IConnector.GetConnectorIdConnectedTo
member.summary: The GetConnectorIdConnectedTo method gets the global ID of the connector, if any, that this connector is connected to.
member.param: Pointer to a string pointer into which the method writes the address of a null-terminated, wide-character string that contains the other connector's global ID. The method allocates the storage for the string. The caller is responsible for freeing the storage, when it is no longer needed, by calling the CoTaskMemFree function. If the GetConnectorIdConnectedTo call fails, *ppwstrConnectorId is NULL. For information about CoTaskMemFree, see the Windows SDK documentation.

returns.para: If the method succeeds, it returns S_OK. If it fails, possible return codes include, but are not limited to, the values shown in the following table.

listheader.description: This connector is not connected, or the other side of the connection is not another device topology (for example, a Software_IO connection).

member.name: IConnector.GetDataFlow
member.summary: The GetDataFlow method gets the direction of data flow through this connector.

param.name: pFlow
param.para: Pointer to a variable into which the method writes the data-flow direction. The direction is one of the following enumeration values:
If data flows into the device through the connector, the data-flow direction is In. Otherwise, the data-flow direction is Out.

returns.para: If the method succeeds, it returns S_OK. If it fails, possible return codes include, but are not limited to, the values shown in the following table.

member.name: IConnector.GetDeviceIdConnectedTo
member.summary: The GetDeviceIdConnectedTo method gets the device identifier of the audio device, if any, that this connector is connected to.
member.param: Pointer to a string pointer into which the method writes the address of a null-terminated, wide-character string that contains the device identifier of the connected device. The method allocates the storage for the string. The caller is responsible for freeing the storage, when it is no longer needed, by calling the CoTaskMemFree function. If the GetDeviceIdConnectedTo call fails, *ppwstrDeviceId is NULL. For information about CoTaskMemFree, see the Windows SDK documentation.

returns.para: If the method succeeds, it returns S_OK. If it fails, possible return codes include, but are not limited to, the values shown in the following table.

listheader.description: This connector is not connected, or the other side of the connection is not another device topology (for example, a Software_IO connection).

member.name: IConnector.GetType
member.summary: The GetType method gets the type of this connector.

param.name: pType
param.para: Pointer to a variable into which the method writes the connector type. The connector type is one of the following enumeration constants:

returns.para: If the method succeeds, it returns S_OK. If it fails, possible return codes include, but are not limited to, the values shown in the following table.

member.name: IConnector.IsConnected
member.summary: The IsConnected method indicates whether this connector is connected to another connector.
member.param: Pointer to a BOOL variable into which the method writes the connection state. If the state is TRUE, this connector is connected to another connector. If FALSE, this connector is unconnected.

returns.para: If the method succeeds, it returns S_OK. If it fails, possible return codes include, but are not limited to, the values shown in the following table.

member.name: IConnector
member.summary:
The IConnector interface represents a point of connection between components. The client obtains a reference to an IConnector interface by calling the or method, or by calling the IPart.QueryInterface method with parameter iid set to REFIID IID_IConnector.
An IConnector interface instance can represent:
An audio jack on a piece of hardware
An internal connection to an integrated endpoint device (for example, a built-in microphone in a laptop computer)
A software connection implemented through DMA transfers
The methods in the IConnector interface can describe various kinds of connectors. A connector has a type (a enumeration constant) and a subtype (a GUID obtained from the method).
A part in a device topology can be either a connector or a subunit. The interface provides methods that are common to connectors and subunits.
For code examples that use the IConnector interface, see the implementations of the GetHardwareDeviceTopology and SelectCaptureDevice functions in Device Topologies.
